citation.article-title: Yania halotolerans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel member of the suborder Micrococcineae from saline soil in China
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Yania [Ya′ni.a. N.L. fem. n. Yania named after Sun-Chu Yan (1912–1994), a Chinese microbiologist who devoted his life to the study of actinomycete taxonomy and antibiotics].
Cells are non-motile, aerobic, Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, coccoid or oval and about 0·4–0·7 μm in diameter and occur singly or in clusters.
Cell-wall peptidoglycan type is A4α, l-lys–gly–l-Glu.
Whole-cell sugars are xylose, mannose and galactose.
Phospholipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol, one unknown phospholipid, one unknown glycolipid and traces of phosphatidylinositol.
Predominant menaquinones are MK-8, MK-7 and MK-9.
Major cellular fatty acids are i-C15 : 0, ai-C15 : 0 and ai-C17 : 0.
The type species is Yania halotolerans.
